title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: Julius Agricola was the first Roman commander who placed garrisons along the isthmus between the rivers Forth and Clyde; most of his forts were on the northern side of the wall built in the reign of Antoninus Pius, a.d. 138 to 160. The venerable Bede fixes the beginning of the wall at old Kirkpatrick, notwithstanding that it was extended to Dunglas between the present Cockburnspath and Innerwick,* and the end to Caerridden on the Frith of Forth, near Abercorn, which in the seventh century was the seat of an English Bishop of the Picts. The length of the wall is 39 Roman miles and 717 paces.
